name: Ashrit Kamireddi
title: Chief Product Officer & Head of Operations

flow.context: Ashrit Kamireddi is Chief Product Officer and Head of Operations at AvantStay — he owns both the product/tech roadmap and day-to-day ops execution, making him the ideal internal sponsor for an AI layer on their existing Breezeway workflow. AvantStay is a tech-enabled vacation rental operator using Breezeway for property ops, Salesforce for CRM, TalkDesk for guest comms, and a proprietary owner portal called Lighthouse — they're actively expanding into hotels with Sense28 opening in Miami in March 2026. Strongest tie to Sam: Ashrit holds an MBA from The Wharton School, and Sam attended the Wharton Entrepreneurship Camp — lead with the shared Wharton thread.

gatekeeper.label: GATEKEEPER — SLIDE BY
gatekeeper.say: Hey, could you get me through to Ashrit? It's Sam.
gatekeeper.note: Don't pitch. Don't explain. Sound like you belong. If Ashrit answers directly, jump straight to opener.

branches.label: Transferred / Ashrit picks up
Who's calling? / What's this about?
He's not available / out of office

gatekeeper_context.label: GATEKEEPER — ADD CONTEXT
gatekeeper_context.say: Yeah, I work with a few other property management companies on their ops workflows. Would you mind letting Ashrit know it's Sam Parks?
gatekeeper_context.note: Still no pitch. Just enough to sound legitimate. Redirect with a question — you ask, you control.

branches.label: Transferred / putting you through
More pushback / what company are you with?
Not available

gatekeeper_social_proof.label: GATEKEEPER — SOCIAL PROOF
gatekeeper_social_proof.say: Totally understand. We help a couple property management companies with their inspection and turnover workflows — I sent Ashrit a note about it. Would you mind giving him a heads up that I called?
gatekeeper_social_proof.note: Last attempt. If they still won't budge, get their name, ask for voicemail, and try again at a different time or route.

branches.label: Transferred / OK I'll let him know
Still won't transfer

gatekeeper_voicemail.label: VOICEMAIL / NOT AVAILABLE
gatekeeper_voicemail.say: No worries at all. Could I leave a quick voicemail? And actually — what's the best time to catch him? I'll try back then.
gatekeeper_voicemail.note: Get timing intel. If leaving a voicemail keep it under 15 seconds: 'Hey Ashrit, it's Sam Parks — I work with a few PM companies on their inspection workflows. Saw the Wharton connection and figured I'd reach out. Give me a ring when you get a sec.' Then call back at the suggested time.

branches.label: They give a callback time
Sent to voicemail / no callback info

opener.label: OPENER — WHARTON CONNECTION
opener.say: Hey Ashrit — this might be a little random. I came across your name doing some research and saw you went through Wharton. I did the Wharton entrepreneurship program a couple years back, so that caught my eye. I'm Sam Parks with RapidEye. Have you heard my name tossed around at all?
opener.note: Wharton is the hook — say it like you're making a genuine connection, not reading a dossier. Pause after the question and let him answer. Feet up on the desk energy.

branches.label: No, I haven't / who?
Yeah, maybe / sounds familiar
Now's not a great time
Confused / skeptical / what is this?

heard_no.label: HAVEN'T HEARD — TRANSITION
heard_no.say: Ha — guess I'm not as popular as I thought. Well the reason for my call — I work with a few property management companies running turnovers at scale, pretty similar setup to you guys. Wanted to run something by you real quick. Got a sec?
heard_no.note: Self-deprecating humor breaks the tension. 'Got a sec?' is a soft permission check. If yes, go to pain. If pushback, go to permission fallback.

branches.label: Sure / go ahead
I'm really busy / what's this about exactly?
Not interested

heard_yes.label: HEARD OF US — EXPLORE
heard_yes.say: Oh nice — well normally we'd be working with someone in exactly your kind of role. What'd you hear?
heard_yes.note: Let him talk. Whatever he says, validate it and steer toward discovery or the pain trigger. If he's vague, he probably hasn't really heard of you — treat it like a soft yes and move to pain.

branches.label: Describes what he heard / asks questions
Vague / not much really
Heard of you but not interested

bad_timing.label: BAD TIMING
bad_timing.say: Totally hear you — would it be a terrible idea if I tried you again later this week? Maybe Thursday or Friday?
bad_timing.note: Don't pitch. Just lock in a callback window. Be specific with days.

branches.label: Gives a time / sure try me then
Just send me an email
Not interested at all

bad_timing_lock.label: LOCK CALLBACK
bad_timing_lock.say: Perfect — I'll give you a ring then. It's Sam Parks with RapidEye. We help PM companies with their turnover inspection workflows. Talk soon, Ashrit.
bad_timing_lock.note: Keep it short. You got the callback — don't oversell. Put it in your calendar immediately.

permission_fallback.label: PERMISSION — ASK FOR 30 SECONDS
permission_fallback.say: Yeah totally — I mean it is a cold call, I'll be straight with you. Can I get 30 seconds to tell you why I reached out? And if it's not relevant you can totally hang up on me.
permission_fallback.note: Honesty disarms. Most people will give 30 seconds if you're upfront. If he says yes, go straight to pain — you're on the clock.

branches.label: Sure / fine, go ahead
No, I'm really not interested

permission_rejected.label: PERMISSION REJECTED
permission_rejected.say: Shoot, totally my bad. Just so nobody from my team bugs you again — is it that I caught you at a horrible time, or is it that you already know what we do and this just isn't interesting?
permission_rejected.note: This split forces a real answer. 'Horrible time' opens a callback. 'Not interesting' tells you about priorities. Either way you learn.

branches.label: It's a bad time
Just not interested / we're covered
What do you actually do?

permission_rejection_split.label: UNDERSTAND THE REJECTION
permission_rejection_split.say: Totally fair. Is it that inspection quality isn't really a priority for you guys right now, or is it more that you just hate cold calls? Honestly either answer is fine.
permission_rejection_split.note: If inspections aren't a priority, you may need a referral to field ops — William Parkhouse is Sr. Director of Field Ops. If he just hates cold calls, offer email.

branches.label: Not a priority / we're good on that
I hate cold calls
Actually — what do you mean by inspection quality?
Hard no / hangs up

pain_trigger.label: PAIN TRIGGER — THE PROBLEM
pain_trigger.say: So I was talking to another product and ops lead at a PM company in a pretty similar spot to you guys — multi-market, using Breezeway for turnovers, scaling fast. His team was running hundreds of turnovers a week, every single one generating photos through Breezeway. But here's the thing — nobody was actually reviewing those photos systematically. Issues were getting caught by guests, not by the team. A stain on a sofa, a cracked tile, a missing set of towels — the photos showed it all, but no one had time to go through every single one. Then it'd show up as a guest complaint or an owner calling in upset. He said the worst part was the data was right there the whole time, sitting in Breezeway, and nobody was doing anything with it.
pain_trigger.note: PAUSE here. Let him react. The Breezeway mention should register — they use it. Do NOT rush into the solution. Let the silence do the work. If he jumps in with 'yeah that sounds like us,' you're golden.

branches.label: Yeah, that sounds familiar / we deal with that
OK so what do you do about it?
We actually have a process for that
Not really our problem / not interested

solution_and_cta.label: ONE-SENTENCE SOLUTION + CTA
solution_and_cta.say: We built an AI layer that sits on top of Breezeway — it analyzes every turnover photo your team's already uploading and flags damage, missing items, staging issues automatically. No workflow change for your field teams at all. Would you be open to seeing what that looks like — maybe when I'm not cold calling you out of the blue?
solution_and_cta.note: One sentence on the product, straight to CTA. Don't over-explain how the AI works. If he says yes, book immediately. If he pushes back, handle the objection.

branches.label: Yeah, I'd be open to that
How does it actually work?
Send me something first
We're not looking for new tools right now
I'm not the right person for this

warm_response.label: THEY'RE WARM — STOP PITCHING, ASK QUESTIONS
warm_response.say: Yeah, that's exactly what we keep hearing. I'm curious — what does your turnover inspection process actually look like right now inside Breezeway? Like, are your field teams uploading photos for every single turnover, and is someone actually reviewing those?
warm_response.note: He's warm. Do NOT pitch more. Ask questions and listen. You're mapping their process so you can tailor the demo perfectly. Take notes on everything he says.

branches.label: Describes their process / shares pain points
Asks more about RapidEye instead
Mentions hotel expansion or new challenges
Actually someone else handles the field stuff

discovery_breezeway.label: DIG INTO BREEZEWAY WORKFLOW
discovery_breezeway.say: That's super helpful. And when something does get flagged — like damage or a maintenance issue — how does that escalation work? Is that flowing through Breezeway into a ticket, or is it more manual than that?
discovery_breezeway.note: You're mapping their escalation workflow: who reviews, how issues get routed, what falls through the cracks. This tells you exactly how RapidEye fits in. When you feel you have enough context, transition to booking.

branches.label: Describes escalation / shares more detail
Asks how RapidEye would fit into that
Mentions scaling challenges or growing pains

discovery_hotel_expansion.label: HOTEL EXPANSION ANGLE
discovery_hotel_expansion.say: That's interesting — and I saw you guys are opening Sense28 in Miami, coming up pretty soon. I'd imagine that adds a whole different layer of complexity to the inspection and maintenance side. How are you thinking about scaling the ops workflows for that?
discovery_hotel_expansion.note: Sense28 hotel opens March 2026 — this is imminent. New property type means new inspection cadence, higher guest expectations, more turnover volume. This creates urgency. Listen for pain around scaling ops for hotels vs. scattered vacation rentals.

branches.label: Yeah, it's a big focus right now
Different team handles the hotel side
Asks how RapidEye helps with hotels

discovery_scale.label: SCALING QUESTION
discovery_scale.say: Makes total sense. And as you guys keep growing — more markets, the hotel, more turnovers every week — what's been the biggest bottleneck on the ops side? Is it the people, the process, or the tools?
discovery_scale.note: This reveals where he feels the pain most. His answer tells you exactly how to frame the demo. After this, transition to booking.

branches.label: Shares the bottleneck / stays engaged
Asks what other companies are doing to solve it
Getting cautious / pulling back

objection_not_interested.label: OBJECTION — NOT INTERESTED
objection_not_interested.say: I totally get it. I should've assumed you'd be all set — otherwise you probably would've reached out to us already.
objection_not_interested.note: Agree first. Don't argue. Pause a beat and let the agreement land before moving to the split.

branches.label: Right / yeah exactly
Wait — what do you actually do?
Hangs up

objection_not_interested_split.label: SPLIT — NOT INTERESTED
objection_not_interested_split.say: Just so no one from my team cold calls you again — is it that turnover inspection quality isn't really on your radar right now, or is it more that you've already got something in place and it's working?
objection_not_interested_split.note: Two very different answers. 'Not on radar' means you might need field ops — William Parkhouse is Sr. Director Field Ops. 'Already have something' opens a conversation about what's working and what's not.

branches.label: Not on our radar / other priorities
We've got something that works
I'm not the right person for this
Hard no

objection_have_process.label: OBJECTION — HAVE A PROCESS
objection_have_process.say: That makes total sense — with the number of properties you guys are managing across all your markets, you'd have to have something dialed in.
objection_have_process.note: Validate their process. They probably use Breezeway checklists plus manual photo review. Don't knock their process — just create curiosity about the gap between having photos and actually analyzing them.

branches.label: Yeah, Breezeway handles it / we're good
It works but it's not perfect
Hangs up

objection_have_process_split.label: SPLIT — HAVE A PROCESS
objection_have_process_split.say: Totally hear you. Is it that you're fully covered and nothing's slipping through the cracks, or is it more that adding anything new right now would just be a headache on top of everything else?
objection_have_process_split.note: 'Nothing slipping through' is a hard claim to make honestly — creates a moment of self-reflection. 'Headache to add' opens the door for the no-workflow-change pitch. Either way you learn.

branches.label: Adding anything would be a headache right now
Honestly, stuff does slip through sometimes
We're fully covered
Hard no

objection_no_budget.label: OBJECTION — NO BUDGET
objection_no_budget.say: Totally get it. Nowadays it's harder to keep a tool, let alone buy something new.
objection_no_budget.note: Agree completely. Budget objections this early in a cold call are reflexive — he hasn't seen pricing. Don't discuss pricing. Move to the split.

branches.label: Yeah, exactly
It's not just budget — we're just not looking

objection_no_budget_split.label: SPLIT — NO BUDGET
objection_no_budget_split.say: Just so I know — is it that budget this cycle is completely locked down, or is it more that anything you try to buy has to go through a whole approval process with Sean and the founders?
objection_no_budget_split.note: Name-dropping Sean Breuner shows you know the org. 'Locked down' means plant a seed for next cycle. 'Approval process' means you need to understand the buying motion — and maybe get to Sean or Reuben directly.

branches.label: Budget is locked / end of year thing
Everything goes through the founders / approval chain
Actually tell me more — what's the cost?

test_drive.label: SELL THE TEST DRIVE
test_drive.say: Look, you're probably not buying anything right now, and I totally respect that. But the people who are ready when budget does free up are the ones who already know what's one, two, and three on their list. If nothing else, I could walk you through what a few other PM companies are doing with their Breezeway turnover photos — worst case you steal some ideas and we part as friends. Would you be open to 20 minutes?
test_drive.note: Low-pressure close. You're not asking him to buy — you're asking him to look. 'Steal some ideas' framing makes the meeting valuable even if they never buy. If yes, lock it in NOW.

branches.label: Yeah, sure / I'd be open to that
Send me something first
Talk to my field ops team — they'd be closer to this
No thanks

send_email_request.label: SEND ME AN EMAIL
send_email_request.say: Totally fair. One quick question before I do — what would be most useful to include so it's not just another generic pitch sitting in your inbox? Like, is it more about how it plugs into Breezeway, or more about what operators your size are seeing in terms of results?
send_email_request.note: This does two things: makes the email actually relevant and tells you what he cares about. Whatever he says, include it and suggest a specific meeting time in the email.

branches.label: Tells you what to include / Breezeway integration
Just send whatever / doesn't care
Actually, let's just find a time now

send_email_confirm.label: CONFIRM EMAIL DETAILS
send_email_confirm.say: Perfect, I'll put something together and get it over to you today. Is your email ashrit at avantstay dot com? And I'll throw a couple time options in there for next week in case you want to hop on a quick call after you've looked it over.
send_email_confirm.note: Confirm the email — this also tests the pattern. Send within the hour. Include a specific time suggestion for Tuesday or Wednesday. Follow up in 2 days if no response.

branches.label: Confirms email / sounds good
Gives a different email address

referral_start.label: REFERRAL — FIND THE RIGHT PERSON
referral_start.say: That's super helpful to know. Who on your team typically owns the turnover inspection workflow day to day? Is that more on the field ops side?
referral_start.note: You know William Parkhouse is Sr. Director of Field Operations. Chloē Buss and Brent Whiteman are Regional Directors of Ops. Don't name-drop them unless Ashrit volunteers a name first — let him tell you.

branches.label: Names someone (William, Chloē, Brent, or other)
Gives a general direction but no name
Doesn't want to refer / pushes back

referral_nudge.label: NUDGE FOR A NAME
referral_nudge.say: Totally understand. Would it be cool if I reached out to your field ops team directly? I just don't want to waste anyone's time with a generic email — if I can get a name, I'll put something tailored together so it actually lands with the right person.
referral_nudge.note: If he still won't give a name, don't push. You already know William Parkhouse, Chloē Buss, and Brent Whiteman from your research. Use what you have and reference talking to Ashrit if he gave implicit permission.

branches.label: Gives a name or title
Won't give a name

referral_get_name.label: GOT THE NAME — ASK TO USE IT
referral_get_name.say: Perfect — and would you mind if I mentioned that you and I spoke? Just so it doesn't feel like a totally random cold outreach on their end.
referral_get_name.note: Getting permission to name-drop Ashrit is huge — it turns the next call from cold to warm. Write down the exact name, title, and anything he says about their role.

branches.label: Sure, go ahead / mention my name
I'd rather you didn't / just reach out on your own

referral_close.label: CLOSE THE REFERRAL
referral_close.say: Really appreciate that, Ashrit. I'll reach out to them and keep it relevant. And hey — if this ever comes back around to your desk on the product side, I'm easy to find. Thanks for your time.
referral_close.note: You got a referral from the CPO. That's a win. Follow up with the referral within 24 hours while Ashrit's memory is fresh. If he gave permission to name-drop, lead with it in the next call opener.

book_meeting.label: BOOK THE MEETING — LOCK IT IN
book_meeting.say: Awesome. Let's get something on the calendar so we're not playing phone tag. I'm looking at next week — how does Tuesday or Wednesday afternoon look for you?
book_meeting.note: Be specific. Two days, let him pick. If he's vague, nail down a day first then a time. Send the invite while still on the phone if possible.

branches.label: Picks a day and time
Next week is packed — week after?
Actually, just send me something first

confirm_meeting.label: CONFIRM AND WRAP
confirm_meeting.say: Perfect — I've got that locked in. I'll send over a calendar invite right now. It'll be a quick 20 minutes — I'll show you what we're doing with a couple other Breezeway operators and you can tell me if it's relevant for AvantStay. Really appreciate you taking my call, Ashrit.
confirm_meeting.note: Send the invite IMMEDIATELY after hanging up. Include a one-line agenda referencing Breezeway and turnover photo analysis. Stop selling — the meeting is booked. End warm.

graceful_exit.label: GRACEFUL EXIT
graceful_exit.say: Totally understand. If anything changes on your end, I'm easy to find — Sam Parks, RapidEye. Appreciate your time, Ashrit.
graceful_exit.note: Don't burn the bridge. He's CPO at a confirmed Breezeway customer scaling into hotels. This lead will come back around. Log the call, note what happened, and plan a follow-up in 4-6 weeks — or pivot to William Parkhouse or Chloē Buss on the field ops side.
